questions.question: Sound is produced by _______ bodies.
questions.explanation: Sound is produced when objects vibrate, creating disturbances in the surrounding medium.

questions.question: The to and fro motion of an object about its mean position is called _______ motion.
questions.explanation: Vibratory or oscillatory motion is the to and fro movement about a rest position.

questions.question: The human voice box is called the _______.
questions.explanation: The larynx is located at the top of the windpipe and contains the vocal cords.

questions.question: In humans, sound is produced by the vibration of _______ _______.
questions.explanation: The vocal cords in the larynx vibrate when air from the lungs passes through them.

questions.question: Sound waves are _______ waves.
questions.explanation: In sound waves, particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question: Sound cannot travel through _______.
questions.explanation: Sound requires a material medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel.

questions.question: The region of high pressure in a sound wave is called _______.
questions.explanation: At compression, particles are crowded together creating high pressure.

questions.question: The region of low pressure in a sound wave is called _______.
questions.explanation: At rarefaction, particles are spread apart creating low pressure.

questions.question: The number of oscillations per second is called _______.
questions.explanation: Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz), where 1 Hz = 1 oscillation per second.

questions.question: The SI unit of frequency is _______.
questions.explanation: Hertz (Hz) is named after the German physicist Heinrich Hertz.

questions.question: The time taken for one complete oscillation is called _______ _______.
questions.explanation: Time period (T) is the reciprocal of frequency: T = 1/f.

questions.question: The maximum displacement from mean position is called _______.
questions.explanation: Amplitude determines the loudness of sound - greater amplitude means louder sound.

questions.question: The distance covered by a wave in one oscillation is called _______.
questions.explanation: Wavelength is represented by the Greek letter lambda (λ).

questions.question: The speed of sound in air is approximately _______ m/s.
questions.explanation: At room temperature (20°C), sound travels at approximately 340 m/s in air.

questions.question: Sound travels fastest in _______.
questions.explanation: Particles in solids are closely packed, allowing faster transmission of vibrations.

questions.question: Sound travels slowest in _______.
questions.explanation: Particles in gases are far apart, causing slower transmission of vibrations.

questions.question: The loudness of sound depends on its _______.
questions.explanation: Greater amplitude produces louder sound.

questions.question: The pitch of sound depends on its _______.
questions.explanation: Higher frequency produces higher pitch (shriller sound).

questions.question: The quality of sound that distinguishes between two sources is called _______.
questions.explanation: Timbre (or quality) helps us identify different voices or instruments.

questions.question: The audible range for humans is _______ Hz to _______ Hz.
questions.explanation: Humans can hear sounds in the frequency range of 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (20 kHz).

questions.question: Sounds with frequency above 20,000 Hz are called _______ sounds.
questions.explanation: Ultrasonic sounds are beyond the upper limit of human hearing.

questions.question: Sounds with frequency below 20 Hz are called _______ sounds.
questions.explanation: Infrasonic sounds are below the lower limit of human hearing.

questions.question: The reflection of sound from a surface is called _______.
questions.explanation: Echo is the repetition of sound due to reflection from a distant surface.

questions.question: For an echo to be heard distinctly, the minimum distance should be _______ metres.
questions.explanation: This ensures a time gap of at least 0.1 seconds between original sound and echo.

questions.question: SONAR stands for Sound _______ and Ranging.
questions.explanation: SONAR = Sound Navigation and Ranging, used to detect underwater objects.

questions.question: _______ use echolocation to navigate in the dark.
questions.explanation: Bats emit ultrasonic sounds and detect objects from the reflected echoes.

questions.question: _______ can produce infrasonic sounds to communicate.
questions.explanation: Elephants produce infrasonic sounds below 20 Hz to communicate over long distances.

questions.question: The unit of loudness is _______.
questions.explanation: Loudness is measured in decibels (dB) on a logarithmic scale.

questions.question: The formula relating speed, frequency and wavelength is v = f × _______.
questions.explanation: Speed (v) = frequency (f) × wavelength (λ).

questions.question: Wavelength is represented by the Greek letter _______.
questions.explanation: Lambda (λ) is the standard symbol for wavelength.

questions.question: In a tuning fork, sound is produced by vibrating _______.
questions.explanation: The prongs (or tines) of a tuning fork vibrate when struck.

questions.question: Guitar, sitar, and veena are _______ instruments.
questions.explanation: These instruments produce sound through vibrating strings.

questions.question: Drum and tabla are _______ instruments.
questions.explanation: Sound is produced by striking a stretched membrane in these instruments.

questions.question: Flute is a _______ instrument.
questions.explanation: In wind instruments, sound is produced by vibrating air column.

questions.question: In harmonium, sound is produced by vibrating _______.
questions.explanation: Reed instruments produce sound when air passes over thin metal strips called reeds.

questions.question: The persistence of hearing in humans is about _______ seconds.
questions.explanation: The human ear retains the sensation of sound for about 0.1 seconds.

questions.question: Multiple reflections of sound in an enclosed space is called _______.
questions.explanation: Reverberation prolongs the sound due to repeated reflections from walls.

questions.question: The speed of sound in water is approximately _______ m/s.
questions.explanation: Sound travels about 4.4 times faster in water than in air.

questions.question: The speed of sound _______ with increase in temperature.
questions.explanation: Higher temperature means faster molecular motion and higher speed of sound.

questions.question: The medical technique using ultrasound to break kidney stones is called _______.
questions.explanation: Lithotripsy uses high-intensity ultrasound to shatter kidney stones.

questions.question: Sound waves are also called _______ waves because they need a medium.
questions.explanation: Mechanical waves require a material medium for propagation.

questions.question: We see lightning before hearing thunder because light travels _______ than sound.
questions.explanation: Light travels at 3 × 10^8 m/s while sound travels at only 340 m/s.

questions.question: The _______ vibrates when sound enters the ear.
questions.explanation: The eardrum (tympanic membrane) converts sound waves to vibrations.

questions.question: Sound waves transfer _______ without transferring matter.
questions.explanation: Sound waves carry energy from one place to another through particle vibrations.

questions.question: A child's voice is shriller because their vocal cords are _______.
questions.explanation: Shorter vocal cords vibrate faster, producing higher frequency (shriller) sound.

questions.question: Frequency and time period are _______ of each other.
questions.explanation: f = 1/T and T = 1/f, so they are inversely related.

questions.question: Density of medium is maximum at _______ in a sound wave.
questions.explanation: At compression, particles are crowded together, increasing density.

questions.question: Pressure is minimum at _______ in a sound wave.
questions.explanation: At rarefaction, particles are spread apart, decreasing pressure.

questions.question: _______ use SONAR to detect fish and submarines.
questions.explanation: Ships use SONAR (ultrasonic waves) for underwater navigation and detection.

questions.question: Normal conversation has a sound level of approximately _______-_______ decibels.
questions.explanation: Normal speech is typically in the 40-60 dB range.
